commentBody:
When I didn't get my favorite toy as a baby, I got rattled.

(But then I'd have a bawl.)

Quick but fun. It felt like it had a few good PECANS, though, to make it crunchy for a Tuesday. 

Thanks, Eric.
Took me a little bit to get the theme. I was trying to tie the words back to MTV!

Spoiler alert:

This puzzle has a rebus. 

(C’mon, *somebody*had to say it!)

Am I just really drunk or was this really hard for a Tuesday? 8:31, that's really slow for me on a Tuesday.

Also, the clueing for 9A seems wrong to me. Isn't the vegetation that prey animals eat considered part of the food chain?
A LIMIT is a "Hard cap"? That's funny — I thought that cap means exactly the same thing as upper limit. It doesn't need to be a "hard" cap to be a limit, because it already is one.
Cluing seemed less straightforward than a typical Tuesday.
Oh hey, a Tuesday puzzle with a REBUS ;)

A little tough for a Tuesday! But a lot of good clues. 

53D is a little meta. Well, but for this puzzle. But as a crossword clue in general. 

I liked 62A. Very clever bit of misdirection. But maybe a higher level of misdirection than you'd usually see on Tuesday!
I like the cuttlefish clue!

Cool puzzle.  Quirky enough to keep us on our toes, and with a little parental guidance, straightforward and fun. 

Thanks, Eric
Whew, harder than im used to for a Tuesday but fun!

Maybe it’s because I haven’t done an early week puzzle in many many months. 

But I found this sneaky hard. Like, as difficult, as some of the recent Fridays.  

I better stick to late week puzzles.  

The theme was clever. I don’t recall the catchphrase, but I remember the show.  

I wanted to enter “you got punked”. But it wasn’t long enough.
So sad to equate MTV with music, poor kids.
Good puzzle, some tricky but fun clues. I finished over my average time for a Tuesday. The fact that I had no idea, and still don't, what the theme clues were all about, did not help my time.
This is unacceptable. What is the editor thinking? After that tough Sunday and Saturday, now they put a REBUS in a Tuesday puzzle?!
That was hard for a Tuesday. I still don’t get the REBUS clue.
I was really committed to 1A biting comment being "sic" which slowed me down in the NW corner.

I misread 16A as “Catcalls of the insurance industry.”

“Hey baby, check out my copay!”
 
“Let me help explain your benefits!”

“We might have to deny a claim that cute!”

I’ll stop now.

Some cluing that was a little trickier than usual for a Tuesday, but crosses did a good job of filling in enough to figure out entries. Stymied myself for having DIs for 1A until the end, but I finally realized what type of net-minder (volleyball?, tennis?, AHA) was being wanted, and filled in the last two letters correctly for the solve. Also briefly had BLANKET cOverage, but none of the crosses worked, so it got fixed in a hurry. No other problems with the theme answers, though. A few answers were guesses, some 'educated', and they turned out to be correct.

My parents made a mistake when I was very young. I was content to stay in my crib and play, but then they had guests over who had a slightly older child, who knew how to climb out of a crib. So, shortly, did I.

Nice puzzle, Eric, hope you're on the way to a full cycle.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/18/tuesday-august-19-2025/#ny
That took more thinking than usual for a Tuesday! Now I need a nap.

.      .   Hooray!

  .      .   Hooray!

  .      .   Hooray!


Thank you, NYT Games team, for another reason to put off doing the dishes . . .

It's been a while since I've struggled like this on a Tuesday. Spent far too much time wondering what RAILINGwAT was because I had RAINwEAR. I also had googleAPP for ages even though I knew ODDoALLS was wrong. I blame the fact that I did it at 4am 😆

Netminder?

That had to refer to the internet, right? Ok, I do alright with technology, but stay away from social media. Hmm. 

I had DIS for 1A. That gave me...SOALIE?

Umm, no. I'm open to learning something new...but, no, that can't be right!

I puzzled over the NW corner, until I realized, DIS was not it. For gosh sakes, I see it now, dang it.

Grrrr! Sports clues, got me again! Lol.
If you get to do today's Midi, there's a bit of a trick, and you could say that it has a sort of similarity to the today's regular puzzle.
I went 40% above my average but enjoyed every minute. I really like the “Book of legends” clue for ATLAS. Thanks, Mr. Rollfing.
Fun and fresh puzzle! Loved the ⚽️ fill, appropriate as the Premier League just kicked off. Go Arsenal!

I realize the crossword has a built-in difficulty sequence throughout the week, but after seeing NYT rank the difficulty on Connections I’d be curious to see something similar for crosswords. 

Maybe I was off today, but felt like a trickier Tuesday. A 4/5 difficulty, if you will!
Agree that it was harder than usual for a Tuesday but entertaining as well! Loved the clue for OMAN :)

I really enjoyed this puzzle! Yes a little trickier for avl Tuesday, but it was lively and kept moving :) A perfect balance between difficulty and enjoyability. I did get tripped up by the American spelling for LIT(RE)!
I find it amusing the Tricky Clues section features all the easy ones (for me).  I was stumped elsewhere

I agree that this was relatively tricky, which is not a bad thing!

I was amused to see REBUS show up, because for a while I was thinking this might actually be a rebus-filled Tuesday. I thought the fig leaf wearer would be David, or maybe Adam. I thought STAIR was “stairs”, SILICA was “desiccant”, ZAPS was “nukes”, and the crabbing spot was my neighbor’s house.

Oh, well. Guess I got punk’d. (Shoutout MTV)

52A: I know that STAIR can be singular or plural and mean the same thing, but in reality, does anyone ever use STAIR to indicate the whole thing, instead of stairs? And not as a modifier, like staircase or stair climber? 

The esteemed Merriam-Webster defines STAIR as "a series of steps or flights of steps for passing from one level to another —often used in plural but singular or plural in construction"
Every example they show us, however, uses plural stairs. 

On another note, I very much wanted to enter bible for 62A, instead of ATLAS. Clever clue, though.
I’m afraid I didn’t recognise any of the long theme entries so needed more help than usual for a Tuesday, not a big problem, still enjoyed the solve.
Really tough for a Tuesday, especially the NW corner

I was thinking the "netminder" could be a fisherman (or -woman), which biased how I dealt with the top left corner: when I saw the third word was A, the biting comment became a DIs, and the Spanish "that" became ESe (one of the other two Spanish endings for said demonstrative pronoun), ultimately leaving me with seALIE and making me believe "sealie" might be a slang term for someone who works on a boat. Luckily it was the only questionable word I had when the site told me I wasn't done yet, and once I thoroughly considered my other options on the Spanish word, DIG and GOALIE fell into place.
Nice photo. What are all those things on the shelves?

Phew. A relief to know it’s not just myself who felt stumped by a Tuesday puzzle. That was a two coffee grid and no mistake. Like @Heidi I was beginning to suspect rebi were involved, not just the REBUS in the clues.

Having finally solved it I can look back and admire the beauty of today’s offering. Being too aged to count myself an MTV watcher the theme revealer was a TIL. My main connection to the channel is Sting’s refrain in Dire Straits ‘Money For Nothing’. That will now be today’s ear worm and there’s nothing wrong with that.

What a perfect Tuesday puzzle.  Beginner friendly due to the crosses, but not a filler-inner for the rest of us.  A number of times, my first thought was not correct, and that doesn't often happen this early in the week.

Tricky Tuesday! I had nothing in the first three rows across until I got to 21A. I suppose I remember that capital because I do the daily crossword. For some reason I always forget poor NEPTUNE (17D) in the list of planets. I was unfamiliar with 2D, so took a wild guess with the “I.” Didn’t know 20A either, but got it from the crossings.

So, is 53D foreshadowing for Thursday?
What happened to the Strands game?
Whew! A good one! In other news, could one of you savants go back to Saturday September 19, 2009 and let me know if that one is actually doable? Thanks!
My time was closer to my Tuesday average than any other day of the week but boy this puzzle did not feel like a Tuesday on first pass.

Clever theme but a really tough Tuesday for me. Needed some crosses for all of the theme answers, and then... was completely unfamiliar with the reveal. That took a while to work out. No big deal - that's all on me. And of course my puzzle finds. Here's a really unusual one - a Thursday from September 24, 2015 by Peter A. Collins. A couple of theme clues and answers: "One volume in the Encyclopedia of Movie Pets and Sidekicks?" TONTOTOTOTOTOME "Statement from the proud snake as its eggs were hatching?" IAMAMAMAMAMBA And the other two theme answers: LENDADADADADA THISISISISISAID Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/24/2015&g=58&d=A Might put another one in a reply. ...

Count me in the "this was tough for me" category. I rarely go above my average time in the early puzzles, but missed my average by a couple of minutes today.

I wasn't really seeing the theme, as evidenced by some of my bigger misses: Komodo instead of MONITOR, umbrella instead of BLANKET. Everything made sense eventually, but it took time.
What would a jaNITORLIZARD even be?
Terrific Tuesday.
Today I realized that Jupiter and Neptune not only have the same number of letters, but also the same third letter.

Today I learned that Uranus is visible to the naked eye under circumstances that I will never have (very dark sky plus very good eyesight). Googling, I find that a lot of people have asked about this, and a lot of those who answer, apparently, are 12 years old.
Tough Tuesday!
Is this where I come to register a complaint about the REBUS in today’s crossword?

If you are getting up there in years like me, today's Brooke Husic puzzle in the New Yorker at https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2025/08/19 is a great challenge for solving a puzzle by figuring out things you don't know. Although Tuesday puzzles are generally considered of medium difficulty, this one leans very heavily towards things younger people might know. But if you're a good solver, you just might be able to push through this one unscathed. In the end, I liked the challenge, although I know many oldies like me are upset that puzzles are now written to include things we don't have an interest in.

V nice Tuesday! Lost a few seconds wondering what a SEALIE might be, then it all clicked into place with GOALIE ha ha - I can never remember Latin or Spanish conjugations that crop up in the puzzles, also confidently thought it was DIS

Often on Tuesdays, my crossword-veteran brain goes into IDLE, settles into recall mode, takes a breather, knowing it will be barking out answers to very-little-effort-to-get direct clues.  Swaths splat in, the puzzle finishes, and while my brain enjoyed keeping in practice, it never got excited.

My brain likes to riddle-crack, to be thrust into a problems that force it to devise possibilities, to unearth connections, to gather different meanings for words, to suddenly see the blanks between crosses. This is what galvanizes my brain.

And today, right from the start, my brain perked up, and before long, it was yessing.  There were vague clues, no-knows, wordplay clues, a theme to crack, clues with humor. 

I left the revealer blank, didn't even look at its clue, and tried to guess it, knowing at that point that it would include CRIB.  And even though I didn’t get it – I never heard of the show – the effort was more balm for my brain.

Then there was the bonus of a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (SNIPS).

Thank you, Eric, for this, for taking my brain from lethargy to happy dance.  More please!

is anyone else having a "bug" with the computer on this today.  it said i finished it last night.  gold star.  every square is filled, and the timer's stopped.  but it shows up as if it's incomplete in the graphic now.  
even if i try to re-complete it, it's stuck / nothing happens.

i don't really care - i gave up the streak idea when i had an issue with my account when i traveled (lost my streak because of nothing related to solving, even after going back and forth with help desk, sour grapes).  
??

Had no idea about the "classic MTV show" or its catchphrase, but filled in WELCOMETOMYCRIB easily enough. The theme played no part in my solving process today. Maybe that's normal for a Tuesday puzzle? This seemed like a solid Tuesday puzzle to me.
I was really disappointed when 58A wasn’t ‘You just got punk’d!’

I'm glad I'm not the only one who struggled with this--the whole NW corner was a mystery to me, given the various meanings the word "net" has taken on. 

A post-solve read of the wikipedia page on "Rebus" gave me a couple of smiles: it included the specific use of the word "rebus" in the context of crossword puzzles, footnoted with a link to Deb's column!
Also I learned that the familial crest of (St.) Ignatius de Loyola--subsequently adopted by various Jesuit institutions--includes the image of two wolves ("lobos") rampant, flanking a cook pot (the crossword staple "OLLA"!)--perhaps a rebus for the name "Loy-Ola." Perhaps not.

Not knowing my MTV, I was guessing CluB before CRIB.
At least I had the REBUS right.

I quite enjoyed this puzzle. Thanks, Eric.

Because I'm reading a great book, Spectacular Things, about a soccer GOALIE, net-minder was my first fill and the rest fortuitously fell into place.

Thanks, Eric - looking forward to more puzzles across the cycle from you!
I really enjoyed this puzzle. Never watched MTV, but the theme was workable. I did realize all of the “baby” references so crib came to me easily. Thanks, Eric!

I got nowhere initially and was a little worried until I got PECAN, and immediately after that RAINGEAR, and then the solve just sort of propagated out from there.

I met an an MTV executive in the early 1980s, before most people (including me) knew of the existence of the internet, and well before the World Wide Web was around. He wasn't what I expected: older, much more corporate, wearing a suit and tie.

I asked him if they'd ever considered a pay cable channel they would provide music...not videos, just music...over cable. You could pick a genre and have a constant ad-free stream of music coming to your stereo. You could tailor it to some really specific tastes.

He literally rolled his eyes.
That photo of the library has to be AI generated. The books on the upper level are way too high to be accessed by anyone, and there's some weird distortions if you look closely.

lol, I got stuck for a few moments due to 48A, where I’d confidently filled in GOOGLEAPP, thinking that it fit the theme very cleverly because it started with something you might hear from a crib — “GOO”

MTV......I have heard of it.  Never watched/listened/cared a fig, so the Reveal was no help and made no sense.
I wanted ODD DUCKS for 37D, which complicated matters further.
The Kinks?  Myst? Play Store? Insta? World Cup?

Babies. I know about babies.  If they really need you, you won't require a MONITOR.  They don't really need BLANKETs (safety tip) ...and a MOBILE is optional.  
Recently we saw an ad for some fancy brand of diapers that only need to be changed after 11 hours. (Plus the ad says, "Less changes" instead of "fewer.")   Hoo boy.  Can you spell "sore bottom"?
Our children (now in their 40's)  were born at the advent of the "artificial diapers" era.  Instant rash!  So we were in the Cloth Diapers Crowd.  You can still get 'em--and I do.  You can't beat 100% cotton for household tasks.

Nomen et omen.

Tell me about it!
6:23 today. The "nominative determinism" clues are always favorites of mine -- they never fair to elicit a chuckle when I actually figure out the pun. Thankfully IRA came pretty quickly today.
Great puzzle!
After reading the truly depressing article about the Geiers and thier shoddy, manipulative autism "research," I needed this puzzle.

Ok, this was pretty annoying. The clue that totally threw me was “netminder”. How …. American can you get? Who on earth in the rest of the non US/Canada world would have any idea about that?

I’ll be grumpy about praline as well. What non-insane nation would put a pecan in there?

I can remember when CRIB was new slang for one's abode, although I was already too old to use it myself.  At the time I remember thinking that it was kinda cute and amusing.

With the help of this puzzle, it now seems worse than juvenile. It's positively infantile!

By the way, does anyone still use this term to refer their "pad"?  It feels to me that its time has come and gone.

And an additional note.  I think the phrase is "nomen EST omen."
A commenter's gotta have a nit.
Enjoyed this puzzle! A lil challenging for me particularly but had some excellent clues and a tight theme set. Nicely done!

I enjoyed this from start to finish. Maybe I’m just in a particularly good mood today, but my morning puzzle solving makes me very happy, and this one really hit the spot. 

Maybe it was the thrill of 4D and 53D breaking the third wall? But hey no need to question why. We don’t need netminders gatekeeping puzzle enjoyment!

Very much enjoyed the choice of cluing in this puzzle. So many of these entries could have been clued many, many ways. The ones that made the cut gave this Tuesday puzzle a fresh feeling. (Like the lovely breeze and cooler temps outside here on the SECT coast. I saw a tall ship coming in while I was out walking this morning.)

A gray and rainy morning off here in Detroit, and the lead photo of Sam's column prompted me to pull down and re-read Jorge Luis Borges' short story "The Library of Babel." If you are unfamiliar, may I recommend it.

could have been the cat limiting my range of motion, but it took me longer than i expect for a tuesday puzzle

happy tuesday, everyone!

WARNING! The following story is not for the easily grossed out.

Back in 2002, there was a local man who had a pair of MONITOR LIZARDs as pets. When concerned neighbors reported a foul odor to the authorities, police found his partially eaten corpse sitting against the wall. (A friend of mine was one of the responding officers.) It was never determined whether the victim was already deceased or merely unconscious when the creatures began feeding on him, but a neighbor claimed the man had recently been bitten by one of the lizards, and had gotten a nasty infection as a result. This gruesome story re-surfaced in the UK Sun a few years ago, for no apparent reason.

Enjoy the rest of your day, everybody.

Very tough for a Tuesday puzzle.  A lot of words from specialized knowledge or just archaic words.  Still don't understand the ETE answer.  And the main theme clue being from an MTV show that aired long after most people stopped watching it.
Not another REBUS puzzle! ;)
I did not enjoy this puzzle. I was expecting the difficulty that came from a tuesday, not what felt like a thursday. I have struggled less on some saturday puzzles.
Tough and satisfying Tuesday solve.
That took a little longer than my Tuesday average, but it was well worth it.
I thought this Tuesday was pretty easy- with lots of clues easier for a youth like me- usually I find clues to be targeted to older demographics so this was refreshing and fun for me

MONITOR not MONSTER doubled my solve time. Also, thought it worked with the theme… monster under the bed anyone?

Great puzzle. I loved the REBUS hint
Too difficult for a Tuesday. Overall enjoyable!

I woke up this morning and almost decided to give up on Monday and Tuesday puzzles. Instead, I slipped into my routine: made my coffee, sat down with the puzzle... and had to think!

Thanks for a crunchier-than-usual Tuesday!
I had WAILING not RAILING for the longest time.
Ahhhh.. a fun theme that actually makes sense :)

MTV Cribs and Myst?! My elder millennial heart overflows with nostalgic joy! 
I thoroughly enjoyed this one, though for the longest time could not let go of a 1a DIs, and chose to accept that "seALIES" must be an esoteric nickname for seals, and they would indeed want to mind the nets. 😂
Also loved the rebus clue. Excellent Tuesday!

My trickiest spot was SEPIA crossing with ROI, primarily because I don't put in answers I'm not sure of on my first pass through the across clues. I tend to find the down clues easier than the across (is it just me, or is that a known thing? I don't know.) I found this a bit more challenging than a normal Tuesday puzzle. Part of my difficulty was that 58A only became clear once I got enough crosses, so I didn't get a boost to the theme entries. Now that the entertainment world is so vast, there are bound to be big gaps in pop culture knowledge and this was one of mine.

With apologies, yet one more late puzzle find. This one was beyond amazing. A Sunday from December 23, 2018 by David Alfred Bywaters with the title LABORCONTRACT(ION)S. This puzzle switched the trick from the top half to the bottom half. The three top-half them answers: 24a: How polka bands get their start? : WITHONEACCORDION 32a: "Pontiff's gold treasure?" PAPALBULLION 53a: "Query about the Freedom Caucus or Berniecrats?" ISTHATAFACTION And in the bottom half: 90a: "Nickname for a hard-to-please girl?" MISSIMPOSSIBLE 109a: "Data maintained by competitive dentists?" FILLINGSTATS 119a: "Speakers' searches for just the right words?" RHETORICALQUESTS And the 'reveal': Like some factories ... or, in a different sense, like 90-, 109- and 119-Across (but not 24-, 32- and 53-Across)? : UNIONIZED Wow. Here's that Word Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/23/2018&g=90&d=A ...

Well that was unpleasant. Never watched (or heard of Cribs) and I don’t know what BLANKET, RAILING, MONITOR and MOBILE refers to with that show either… On top of that I felt a lot of the answers were odd uses, not necessarily wrong but just not used often. This seemed more like a Thursday than a Tuesday. Worst part of that is after slogging through this I still have 3 days left of work.. 😂
Loved 21 across! Thanks for the treat.

I've never heard of the show at 58A, and had to look it up. When I think "classic MTV" as in the clue, I think of the mid to late 80s, which is when I watched it (and when they were primarily devoted to showing music videos). Haven't seen it since then.

And... even one more puzzle find. I'll probably re-post this tomorrow. A Sunday from June 4, 1995 by Bryant White with the title "One up." Some theme clue and answer examples: "Cat's Eye" novelist? MARGARETATHREEOD "Best Actor of 1955?" ERNESTBORGTEN "Onetime British Prime Minister?" ARTHURBALFIVE "Four-time Pulitzer-winning playwright?" EUGENETWOILL ""Funeral in Berlin" author?" LENDNINEON "Noted mountaineer?" ELEVENZINGNORGAY "1960 World Series hero?" BILLMAONESKI And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/4/1995&g=129&d=A ...
Pretty tough for a Tuesday, but still enjoyable.
An eye for an I.  Hilarious!  Thank you, Eric.

Since "Cribs" was popular in the early 00s this puzzle is more up the alley of Millennials. I dare say this forum is more composed of Boomers. Nothing wrong with that, but the complaints make sense to me.
Spelling caused me at least 5 minutes. Oh well, someday I'll spell gooder.
Really delightful puzzle. Being a Baby Boomer meant I had trouble with the MTV theme, but I got there eventually. Thanks for the fun, Eric Rollfing.
Couldn't get the revealer even with like half of the letters, going "wellcome doesn't fit..." I think I need to go to bed
Disliked this one a lot. Terrible clues.
Hahahaha! A time for us millennials to shine! Thanks for the delightful puzzle.
got confused initially, because coincidentally “you just got punkd” is the same number of letters as the actual answer for the mtv clue

@Mike

This one should have had a spoiler alert.

@Mike

Fanatic railingat the injustices of playthings could lead to reversal of formula . . . Welcometomybib 😉

@Mike
This makes 2 days in a row I'm drawing a blanky.
@NYC Traveler yes, two others before you did 😉
@NYC Traveler disregard my previous comment 🤣 I always sort by oldest comments first, but my phone updated today and it defaults to newest comment first 🤦🏼‍♀️

@Steven M.
Around eight minutes is my usual Tuesday solve time.  Tonight it was 10:39.  Even though hard at first, it eventually softened.

@Steven M. That was one answer I put in right away, even though I was dubious about it. If the predator is at the top, then its prey is just one step below. If that’s the bottom, it’s a pretty short chain!

@Steven M.
Definitely harder than a typical Tuesday IMO.  Part of what made it challenging, I think, is that some of the theme answers were more vaguely clued than a typical Tuesday, so things like RAILING AT and MONITOR LIZARD didn't jump out at the solver, as can often happen earlier in the week.

@Steven M. Not just you. I made my first pass through the across clues and was shocked by how little I had filled in. Took awhile before it finally broke open, and I ended up a good 20% over my normal Tuesday time.

@Steven M.

This is what xwstats.com had to say about it:

Global Stats
Difficulty
Very Hard
Median Solve Time
8:19
Median Solver
18% slower
⚡26% of users solved faster than their Tuesday average.
9% solved much faster (>20%) than their Tuesday average.
🐢74% of users solved slower than their Tuesday average.
48% solved much slower (>20%) than their Tuesday average.

I solved it in considerably less time than their median time, but still about 13% slower than my Tuesday average.  I did notice, though, a bit of crunchiness as I was doing it.

@Steven M. I found it quite hard! The clues were just a little trickier/quirkier than a typical Tuesday. Loved it but solved well below my average time.

Enjoyed EVE as a counterpart to ADAM from yesterday.

@Steven M. Hopefully an actual ecologist or zoologist will weigh in, but prey can be used for plants or fungus or other non-animal foods. Also (responding to the "very short chain" comment), predators can be prey for other species.
@Niki B OMG I meant well above my average time, didn't mean to sound like a big braggart there.
@Steven M. And I was rooting for SOIL, but nothing grew on it.

@Steven M.
I came within 30 seconds of my average time, and had to hunt for one wrong letter before I got the happy music -- I had DIs -- but I knew sOALIE was wrong.  I was thinking Internet, not sports....

@Dan

Maybe a little redundant, but I might put a cap on my spending, and then cheat sometimes, but if I put a hard cap on it then that really is the LIMIT
I've never run into a speed limit that was called a cap.

@JM

I know, wasn’t it wonderful?

@JM
At first, I didn't know any of the answers, until one third of the way down, I got one, and then another, etc...  It was satisfying, though.

@Isabeau

What will the REBUS haters say?

@Weak

Nah, it was relatively hard...

Xwstats.com says:

Global Stats
Difficulty
Very Hard
Median Solve Time
8:19
Median Solver
18% slower
⚡26% of users solved faster than their Tuesday average.
9% solved much faster (>20%) than their Tuesday average.
🐢74% of users solved slower than their Tuesday average.
48% solved much slower (>20%) than their Tuesday average.

@JayTee

Wonderful few minutes you gave me there.

If there is a galactic or inter-galactic award show for a most astonishing, stupendous open to an entertainment channel, MTV's explosive introduction would have to be a leading contender.

Mark Knopfler is a genius, but not the kind I'd hate to ever have to meet.  He seems to understand he is human, unlike so many others.

@JayTee
Classic MTV for sure! I loved how creative it was in the beginning!

@Asher the catchphrase “welcome to my crib” is from the show Cribs, where celebrities gave tours of their homes. The starts of the theme entries all have something you would find in a baby’s crib. Hope this helps!

@T

Lol

@Ernest. In the world outside the NYT xwords, the type of puzzles where an image, say a picture of an eye, is substituted for a word or part of word, often as homophones, so that eye stands for I, is called a REBUS.

@Ernest

Outside of the NYT crossword, a rebus is a phrase that uses pictures in place of letters. So, for example, a picture of an eye instead of the word "I".

Even in the NYT Crossword, a rebus can mean what it means everywhere else, as Deb notes in the article linked in the column:

     "A rebus can be a letter, a number or a symbol that represents a word, but in many crosswords, the rebus will be a word or group of letters that needs to be written inside a single square."

There were rebuses in the Crossword for years before the first "squish" of more than one letter in a box.

@MamaIshtari

I had DIs at first

@MamaIshtari
I wanted to”arf.”

@MamaIshtari

I had wit.

@MamaIshtari

I wanted “yum”
@Heidi I had CUT because I very much wanted 1D to be COSTS.
@Cat Lady Margaret It’s the wolf whistle of Wall Street

@Cat Lady Margaret,

“I got ya deductible right heah!”
@Cat Lady Margaret HAHAHAHAHA 😍😍😍😍😍
"Whoa baby, if like to put a rider on THAT policy!!"
@Francis: ha, I am a transplant. (But your intel about Maine natives is incorrect.)

@JayTee for some reason, my brain wanted it to be a fishing net and at one point I was considering TOADIE as some sort of insult to the person who minds the net while the cool kids get to fish. 

🐟

@Eric Hougland

Why would you say this theme is infantile?
@Elizabeth Connors I’m guessing maybe because it’s about things you find in an infant’s crib?

@Jacqui J

That’s it exactly (hence my description of it as “literally . . . infantile”).

@CLN Exact same here. lol

@CLN
I had DIS, also.
However, the clue tells you it's Spanish for "that."  It is NOT a conjugation, just a matter of whether 'that' refers to a feminine or a masculine place/thing/person.  So you put in ES- and wait to see if it needs to be an O or an A.

English is so much more convenient, not assigning gender to nouns and then requiring that modifiers agree....

@Mean Old Lady

Not quite.  

ESE is the masculine form:  ESE libro es rojo.

ESA is the feminine form:  ESA pluma es roja.

ESO is the neuter form, used when there's no noun at all:  ¿Qué es ESO?

But you are correct that this is not an example of a conjugation.

@Stephen D

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Praline

Pralin (crushed praline)
Type	Confectionery
Place of origin	Belgium
Main ingredients	nuts, syrup
Variations	European, American
 Cookbook: Praline
  Media: Praline

American pralines cooling on a marble slab. Unlike European pralines, American pralines are made with cream.
Pralines (US: /ˈpreɪliːn/; New Orleans, Cajun, and UK: /ˈprɑːliːn/) are confections containing nuts – usually almonds, pecans and hazelnuts – and sugar. Cream is a common third ingredient.

There are two main types:

French pralines, a firm combination of almonds or hazelnuts, and caramelized sugar
American pralines, a softer, creamier combination of syrup and pecans, hazelnuts or almonds with milk or cream, resembling fudge
A praline cookie is a chocolate cookie containing ground nuts. Praline is usually used as a filling in chocolates or other sweets.
